elements.content: Four barrel-shaped artificial molecular capsules based on cucurbit[5]uril, [K4(C30H30N20O10)2(HCONH2)2(H2O)2Cl2]Cl2·CH3OH·17.5H2O (1), {[Ba2(C30H30N20O10)Cl](NO3)(H2O)5}Cl2·2H2O (2), [Cd(C30H30N20O10)Cl2](H3O)2 2+CdCl4 2-·2CH3OH2·4H2O (3), and {[La(C30H30N20O10)Cl]LaCl(H2O)9}Cl4·HCl·7H2O (4) were synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffractions. The crystal structure of these compounds show that chlorine anions were encapsulated in cucurbit[5]uril to form open or closed molecular capsules. 1 forms a novel one-dimensional (1D) polycationic chain in the solid state and the other three molecular capsules crystallize in isolated molecules.
elements.clean_text: Four barrel-shaped artificial molecular capsules based on cucurbit[5]uril, [K4(C30H30N20O10)2(HCONH2)2(H2O)2Cl2]Cl2⋅CH3OH⋅17.5H2O (1), {[Ba2(C30H30N20O10)Cl](NO3)(H2O)5}Cl2⋅2H2O (2), [Cd(C30H30N20O10)Cl2](H3O)2 2+CdCl4 2-⋅2CH3OH2⋅4H2O (3), and {[La(C30H30N20O10)Cl]LaCl(H2O)9}Cl4⋅HCl⋅7H2O (4) were synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffractions. The crystal structure of these compounds show that chlorine anions were encapsulated in cucurbit[5]uril to form open or closed molecular capsules. 1 forms a novel one-dimensional (1D) polycationic chain in the solid state and the other three molecular capsules crystallize in isolated molecules.

elements.content: Four barrel-shaped artificial molecular capsules based on cucurbit[5]uril coordinating to metallic cation and encapsulating naked anion chlorine inside the capsules were synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text: Four barrel-shaped artificial molecular capsules based on cucurbit[5]uril coordinating to metallic cation and encapsulating naked anion chlorine inside the capsules were synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: In past 40 years, although the field of coordination chemistry of cations has become well developed, the chemistry of anion encapsulation is still in its infancy. Recently, host molecules for anions are becoming a field of great interest. There are a number of reasons for this new host−guest chemistry. Anions are ubiquitous throughout biological systems, and they also play important roles in the areas of templation (or directed self-assembly), catalysis, environmental pollution, and so on. The design and synthesis of anion receptors are particularly challenging. The main reason is that anions have a lower charge-to-radius ratio so as to have less effective electrostatic binding interactions than do isoelectronic cations.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In past 40 years, although the field of coordination chemistry of cations has become well developed, the chemistry of anion encapsulation is still in its infancy. Recently, host molecules for anions are becoming a field of great interest. There are a number of reasons for this new host-guest chemistry. Anions are ubiquitous throughout biological systems, and they also play important roles in the areas of templation (or directed self-assembly), catalysis, environmental pollution, and so on. The design and synthesis of anion receptors are particularly challenging. The main reason is that anions have a lower charge-to-radius ratio so as to have less effective electrostatic binding interactions than do isoelectronic cations.

elements.content: Many host molecules for including halide anions have been synthesized and studied. In 1968, Park and Simmons synthesized the earliest macrocyclic receptor for anions, which coordinate to halide anions using electrostatic interactions and hydrogen bonds together. Hawthorne and co-workers used mercury as a Lewis-acidic center in a number of halide anion receptors. Recently, Sessler and Kohnke reported that calix[n]pyrroles and their derivatives may coordinate to halide anions through hydrogen bonds, and Kim presented other anion receptors with imidazole derivatives.
elements.clean_text: Many host molecules for including halide anions have been synthesized and studied. In 1968, Park and Simmons synthesized the earliest macrocyclic receptor for anions, which coordinate to halide anions using electrostatic interactions and hydrogen bonds together. Hawthorne and co-workers used mercury as a Lewis-acidic center in a number of halide anion receptors. Recently, Sessler and Kohnke reported that calix[n]pyrroles and their derivatives may coordinate to halide anions through hydrogen bonds, and Kim presented other anion receptors with imidazole derivatives.

elements.content: Cryptands, which are the most fascinating macrobicyclic systems, possess intramolecular cavities that are available for the encapsulation of anion guests. Cucurbit[n = 5−8]uril, (here after abbreviated as Q[n]) (Figure ), are a relatively new family of molecular hosts. These macrocycles have an intrinsic capacity and two identical carbonyl-fringed portals on each side. Research on Q[n] has demonstrated the binding of guests such as xenon, tetrahydrofuran, cis-SnCl4(OH2)2, piperazine, and water molecules within the cyclic host. However, to the best our knowledge, no Q[n] that encapsulates anions has been reported so far. To investigate the capability of Q[n] inclusion anions and their potential application, we designed and synthesized some complex compounds of Q[5] in which “naked” anion is encapsulated, and herein we described the synthesis and crystal structures of four Q[5] molecular capsules encapsulating chlorine anion.
elements.clean_text: Cryptands, which are the most fascinating macrobicyclic systems, possess intramolecular cavities that are available for the encapsulation of anion guests. Cucurbit[n = 5-8]uril, (here after abbreviated as Q[n]) (Figure ), are a relatively new family of molecular hosts. These macrocycles have an intrinsic capacity and two identical carbonyl-fringed portals on each side. Research on Q[n] has demonstrated the binding of guests such as xenon, tetrahydrofuran, cis-SnCl4(OH2)2, piperazine, and water molecules within the cyclic host. However, to the best our knowledge, no Q[n] that encapsulates anions has been reported so far. To investigate the capability of Q[n] inclusion anions and their potential application, we designed and synthesized some complex compounds of Q[5] in which "naked" anion is encapsulated, and herein we described the synthesis and crystal structures of four Q[5] molecular capsules encapsulating chlorine anion.

elements.content: General. Chemicals, such as potassium chloride, barium nitrate, cadmium chloride, and lanthanide nitrate were of commercial quality and used without further purification. Q[5] was synthesized by published procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General. Chemicals, such as potassium chloride, barium nitrate, cadmium chloride, and lanthanide nitrate were of commercial quality and used without further purification. Q[5] was synthesized by published procedures.

elements.content: Crystal Structure Determination. The data were collected on a Bruker Apex-2000 CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with ω scan mode. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. Structural solution and full matrix least-squares refinement based on F 2 were performed with the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 program package, respectively. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated.
elements.clean_text: Crystal Structure Determination. The data were collected on a Bruker Apex-2000 CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with ω scan mode. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. Structural solution and full matrix least-squares refinement based on F 2 were performed with the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 program package, respectively. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated.

elements.content:
A summary of the crystallographic data, data collection, and refinement parameters for compounds 1−4 is given in Table .

Synthesis. [K 4 (C 30 H 30 N 20 O 10 ) 2 (HCONH 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 Cl 2 ]Cl 2 · CH 3 OH · 17.5H 2 O (1). Q[5] (1.66 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in 1.5 M hydrochloric acid (100 mL). To this solution (10 mL) was added potassium chloride (0.038 g, 0.05 mmol). The mixture was heated to dissolve the reactants. The filtered solution was set aside for three months to allow crystals to deposit.

Q[5] (1.66 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in 1.5 M hydrochloric acid (100 mL). To this solution (10 mL) was added potassium chloride (0.038 g, 0.05 mmol). The mixture was heated to dissolve the reactants. The filtered solution was set aside for three months to allow crystals to deposit.

The solution was left in an open beaker for about three months. Colorless crystals of 4 were separated and dried on a filter paper.

The solution was left in an open beaker for about three months. Colorless crystals of 4 were separated and dried on a filter paper.

elements.content: Complex 1. Slow vapor evaparation of hydrochloric acid aqueous solution containing KCl and Q[5] results in the formation of crystals of 1. The X-ray crystal structure of 1 (Figure ) reveals that four potassium ions are coordinated to each portal of two Q[5] molecules because the carbonyl groups at the portal of Q[5] can provide metal ion binding sites. K1 is octa-coordinated by five carbonyl oxygens (O1, O3, O4, O3A, and O4A), two water molecules (O1W, O1WA), and a chlorine anion (Cl1). K2 and K4 are all coordinated by six carbonyl oxygens and a chlorine anion. K3 is coordinated by five carbonyl oxygens, two nitrogens, and a chlorine anion. Interestingly, the four potassium ions effectively cover each portal of Q[5] like a lid on a barrel. One chlorine anion resides in the cavity of the potassium ion “lidded” Q[5]. So, two Q[5] molecules, four potassium cations, and two chlorine anions form two unadulterated molecular capsules. The most remarkable feature in 1 is that the two bridging chlorine anions Cl(1) and Cl(2) in 2 have close K···Cl contacts of 3.106(2), 3.056(2), 3.037(2), and 3.037(2) Å, which are shorter than in crystalline KCl, 3.138 Å. The reason is that each potassium cation is defined by five carbonyl oxygens. Furthermore, Q[5]-based molecular capsules formed a novel one-dimensional polycationic chain in which lidded Q[5] molecules link to one another through coordination of their carbonyl groups to the potassium cations in between (Figure ). The interchain space is filled with chlorine anions, chloride acids, and water molecules that form a complicated hydrogen-bonding network among themselves.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Complex 1. Slow vapor evaparation of hydrochloric acid aqueous solution containing KCl and Q[5] results in the formation of crystals of 1. The X-ray crystal structure of 1 (Figure ) reveals that four potassium ions are coordinated to each portal of two Q[5] molecules because the carbonyl groups at the portal of Q[5] can provide metal ion binding sites. K1 is octa-coordinated by five carbonyl oxygens (O1, O3, O4, O3A, and O4A), two water molecules (O1W, O1WA), and a chlorine anion (Cl1). K2 and K4 are all coordinated by six carbonyl oxygens and a chlorine anion. K3 is coordinated by five carbonyl oxygens, two nitrogens, and a chlorine anion. Interestingly, the four potassium ions effectively cover each portal of Q[5] like a lid on a barrel. One chlorine anion resides in the cavity of the potassium ion "lidded" Q[5]. So, two Q[5] molecules, four potassium cations, and two chlorine anions form two unadulterated molecular capsules. The most remarkable feature in 1 is that the two bridging chlorine anions Cl(1) and Cl(2) in 2 have close K⋅⋅⋅Cl contacts of 3.106(2), 3.056(2), 3.037(2), and 3.037(2) Å, which are shorter than in crystalline KCl, 3.138 Å. The reason is that each potassium cation is defined by five carbonyl oxygens. Furthermore, Q[5]-based molecular capsules formed a novel one-dimensional polycationic chain in which lidded Q[5] molecules link to one another through coordination of their carbonyl groups to the potassium cations in between (Figure ). The interchain space is filled with chlorine anions, chloride acids, and water molecules that form a complicated hydrogen-bonding network among themselves.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of1; solvate water molecules and anions are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  X-ray crystal structure of1; solvate water molecules and anions are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: One-dimensional coordination polymer in1.
elements.clean_text: 3  One-dimensional coordination polymer in1.

elements.content: Complex 2. The compound 2 was obtained by the reaction of Q[5] with the Ba(NO3)2·2H2O in HCl (3 M) solution. Within two weeks, well-shaped colorless crystals suitable for X-ray studies separate in high yield. In the crystals of 2 (Figure ), {[Ba2(C30H30N20O10)Cl](NO3)(H2O)5}Cl2·2H2O two barium ions are located at the center of each portal of Q[5] just as the crystal of 1, in which each metal cation is coordinated by five carbonyl oxygens. The bariums-containing cation, [Ba2(C30H30N20O10)Cl](NO3)(H2O)5 2+, is separated, and there are many solvent molecules and chlorine anions around it. Obviously, the separated cation is a closed molecular capsule, in which the anion chlorine (Cl1) is encapsulated.
elements.clean_text: Complex 2. The compound 2 was obtained by the reaction of Q[5] with the Ba(NO3)2⋅2H2O in HCl (3 M) solution. Within two weeks, well-shaped colorless crystals suitable for X-ray studies separate in high yield. In the crystals of 2 (Figure ), {[Ba2(C30H30N20O10)Cl](NO3)(H2O)5}Cl2⋅2H2O two barium ions are located at the center of each portal of Q[5] just as the crystal of 1, in which each metal cation is coordinated by five carbonyl oxygens. The bariums-containing cation, [Ba2(C30H30N20O10)Cl](NO3)(H2O)5 2+, is separated, and there are many solvent molecules and chlorine anions around it. Obviously, the separated cation is a closed molecular capsule, in which the anion chlorine (Cl1) is encapsulated.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of2.
elements.clean_text: 4  X-ray crystal structure of2.

elements.content: Complex 3. The synthesis of compounds 3 is straightforward too. It was obtained by the reaction of Q[5] with aqueous solutions of cadmium chloride at room temperature. Two days later, well-shaped colorless crystals suitable for X-ray diffractions crystallize from the solution in high yield. In the crystal structure of 3 (Figure ), one cadmium ion is located at the center of the portal of Q[5] just as the crystal structure of 1, in which the metal cation is coordinated by five carbonyl oxygens (O1, O2, O3, O4, and O5), a chloride anion (Cl2) from outside with a distance of 2.4067(15) Å, and a chlorine anion (Cl1) from inside with a distance of 2.4206(15) Å. In other words, the chlorine cation is encapsulated inside Q[5]. The Q[5] remains one portal open with a water molecule occupying the center with a hydrogen bond.
elements.clean_text: Complex 3. The synthesis of compounds 3 is straightforward too. It was obtained by the reaction of Q[5] with aqueous solutions of cadmium chloride at room temperature. Two days later, well-shaped colorless crystals suitable for X-ray diffractions crystallize from the solution in high yield. In the crystal structure of 3 (Figure ), one cadmium ion is located at the center of the portal of Q[5] just as the crystal structure of 1, in which the metal cation is coordinated by five carbonyl oxygens (O1, O2, O3, O4, and O5), a chloride anion (Cl2) from outside with a distance of 2.4067(15) Å, and a chlorine anion (Cl1) from inside with a distance of 2.4206(15) Å. In other words, the chlorine cation is encapsulated inside Q[5]. The Q[5] remains one portal open with a water molecule occupying the center with a hydrogen bond.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of3; solvate water molecules and anions are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 5  X-ray crystal structure of3; solvate water molecules and anions are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Complex 4. The compound 4 was obtained from a hydrochloric acid solution containing lanthanum nitrate and Q[5]. Its structure is shown in Figure . Obviously, the structure of 4 is quite different from that of 1. The X-ray crystal structure of 4 (Figure ) shows that only one lanthanum cation is a “lid” on Q[5]. The included chlorine anion is coordinated to the “lid” lanthanum cation, and three water molecules (O1W, O2W, and O3W) are also bound to the “lid” lanthanum cation from outside with distances of 2.552(3), 2.614(3), and 2.579(3) Å. The other lanthanum ion just “lean” toward the other side of the portal of Q[5], being coordinated to only two carbonyl oxygen atoms (O7, O9) at the portal with La−O distances of 2.512(3) and 2.613(3) Å. Still six water molecules (O4W, O5W, O6W, O7W, O8W, and O9W) and a chloride (Cl2) ion are coordinated to the lanthanum ion from the outside. A “lid” lanthanum ion, a “lean” lanthanum ion, and a Q[5] molecule formed a open molecular capsule, in which a chlorine anion (Cl1) is encapsulated. The open molecular capsule is separated, and there are a lot of solvent molecules (such as water and HCl) around it.
elements.clean_text: Complex 4. The compound 4 was obtained from a hydrochloric acid solution containing lanthanum nitrate and Q[5]. Its structure is shown in Figure . Obviously, the structure of 4 is quite different from that of 1. The X-ray crystal structure of 4 (Figure ) shows that only one lanthanum cation is a "lid" on Q[5]. The included chlorine anion is coordinated to the "lid" lanthanum cation, and three water molecules (O1W, O2W, and O3W) are also bound to the "lid" lanthanum cation from outside with distances of 2.552(3), 2.614(3), and 2.579(3) Å. The other lanthanum ion just "lean" toward the other side of the portal of Q[5], being coordinated to only two carbonyl oxygen atoms (O7, O9) at the portal with La-O distances of 2.512(3) and 2.613(3) Å. Still six water molecules (O4W, O5W, O6W, O7W, O8W, and O9W) and a chloride (Cl2) ion are coordinated to the lanthanum ion from the outside. A "lid" lanthanum ion, a "lean" lanthanum ion, and a Q[5] molecule formed a open molecular capsule, in which a chlorine anion (Cl1) is encapsulated. The open molecular capsule is separated, and there are a lot of solvent molecules (such as water and HCl) around it.

elements.content: As has been mentioned, all four coordinated compounds encapsulate anions to form molecular capsules. (The first one formed a novel one-dimensional polycationic chain, and the other three are a separate molecule or cation.) The major reason for formation of these molecular capsules is electrostatic interactions. The carbonyl groups at the portal of Q[5] can provide metal ion binding sites, and when metal ion is chelated to carbonyl oxygen, the molecular capsule shell exhibits a high affinity for anions. The strong electrostatic interactions between the metal cations and the anions lead to the formation of open or closed molecular capsules that encapsulate anion. Of course, among the various approaches for recognition and complexation, there are also those that take advantage of hydrogen bonds9 and Lewis acidic8 between anionic guests and receptors containing metal entities. In the present case of the simultaneous encapsulation of chlorine anions, there appears to be electrostatic interactions in operation. In addition, hydrophobic effect of the Q[5] cavity must be taken into account, and complementarily between the receptor and the anion is clearly crucial in determining selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

As has been mentioned, all four coordinated compounds encapsulate anions to form molecular capsules. (The first one formed a novel one-dimensional polycationic chain, and the other three are a separate molecule or cation.) The major reason for formation of these molecular capsules is electrostatic interactions. The carbonyl groups at the portal of Q[5] can provide metal ion binding sites, and when metal ion is chelated to carbonyl oxygen, the molecular capsule shell exhibits a high affinity for anions. The strong electrostatic interactions between the metal cations and the anions lead to the formation of open or closed molecular capsules that encapsulate anion. Of course, among the various approaches for recognition and complexation, there are also those that take advantage of hydrogen bonds9 and Lewis acidic8 between anionic guests and receptors containing metal entities. In the present case of the simultaneous encapsulation of chlorine anions, there appears to be electrostatic interactions in operation. In addition, hydrophobic effect of the Q[5] cavity must be taken into account, and complementarily between the receptor and the anion is clearly crucial in determining selectivity.

elements.content: The capability of entrapping an atomic size guest in Q[n]'s cavity makes it a promising candidate for various applications in chemistry. Moreover, this new example of Q[5] exhibited the remarkably rare property of encapsulating a negatively charged ion. Its easy synthesis, rigid structure, and chemical and thermal stability make Q[n] very attractive for complexation of anions or other guests in aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text: The capability of entrapping an atomic size guest in Q[n]'s cavity makes it a promising candidate for various applications in chemistry. Moreover, this new example of Q[5] exhibited the remarkably rare property of encapsulating a negatively charged ion. Its easy synthesis, rigid structure, and chemical and thermal stability make Q[n] very attractive for complexation of anions or other guests in aqueous solution.

elements.content: In conclusion, for the first time, we have reported a novel artificial organic host molecule for anion in which “naked” chlorine was encapsulated. Further investigations are underway to determine whether the chlorine can be exchanged for other anions and whether the other Q[n] can be used as receptors for the other anionic guests.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, for the first time, we have reported a novel artificial organic host molecule for anion in which "naked" chlorine was encapsulated. Further investigations are underway to determine whether the chlorine can be exchanged for other anions and whether the other Q[n] can be used as receptors for the other anionic guests.
